Technical Assistance for the Asian 
Development Bank’s Continued 
Participation in the Cities Alliance 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
August 2005

ABBREVIATIONS 
 
ADB  –  Asian Development Bank 
CA  –  Cities Alliance 
CDS  –  City Development Strategy 
CWS  –  Cities Without Slums 
DMC  –  developing member country 
GDP  –  gross domestic product

TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE CLASSIFICATION 
 
Sector  –  Multisector 
Subsectors  –  Integrated urban development, water supply and sanitation, and 
housing construction

sustainability

NOTE 
 
In this report ”$” refers to US dollars. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
This report was prepared by K.E. Seetharam.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  Cities Alliance (CA)1 is a global partnership of bilateral2 and multilateral development 
agencies and the world’s major international associations of local authorities3 committed to 
reducing urban poverty. Launched by the World Bank and United Nations Human Settlements 
program (UN-Habitat) in 1999, CA helps cities meet the challenges of the 21st century by 
promoting pro-poor policies, good governance, and the development of prosperous cities free of 
slums. It has partnered with 150 cities in 27 countries. 
 
2.  CA  has  mobilized  pledges  of  contributions  amounting  to  $70  million  for  program 
preparation,  pilot  activities  for  urban  upgrading,  city  development  strategies  (CDSs),  and 
capacity  building  of  cities.  The  heads  of  state  who  signed  the  United  Nations  Millennium 
Declaration have endorsed CA’s Cities Without Slums (CWS) action plan and incorporated it 
into the Millennium Development Goals. CA operates a grant facility for partners to finance 
poverty reduction programs in their cities, which ADB, as a member, has accessed. CA has 
approved grant allocations totaling $48.2 million as of June 2004 and is seeking to increase its 
core funds4 to $115.0 million by 2005. 
 
3.  ADB became a member of CA through an agreement signed with the International Bank 
for Reconstruction and Development and the International Development Association in 2002. 
ADB met its annual contribution of $250,000 in 2002/03 and 2003/04 to the CA’s core funds 
through  regional  technical  assistance  (TA)  60265  and  TA  6151.6  ADB  has  participated  in 
international conferences to present its policies supporting urban development in the region. 
ADB has pilot-tested the preparation of CA’s two key approaches—CDS and CWS7 in five 
cities—which are highly relevant to ADB’s urban operations. ADB also has access to CA’s body 
of knowledge and lessons learned and good practices on reducing urban poverty. ADB is 
represented in the CA Consultative Group, which guides the CA’s policies and work program. 
ADB  is  continuing  its  membership  in  CA  through  a  new  TA.8  The  design  and  monitoring 
framework is in the Appendix. 
 
                                                 
1  http://www.citiesalliance.org 
2  Canada, France, Germany, Italy, Japan, Netherlands, Norway, Sweden, United Kingdom, and United States. 
3  International Union of Local Authorities, Metropolis, United World Federation of United Cities (formerly United 
Towns Organization), and World Assembly of Cities and Local Authorities.  
4  Core funded activities are donor-identified projects that in all respects meet the criteria of CA core funded projects. 
Non-core funded activities are budgeted from CA Trust Fund, which is made by partners over and above their core

7  The World Bank uses the CDS, which is an agile planning instrument that identifies and packages viable 
investments. The World Bank’s East Asia urban sector unit credits CDS work in the People’s Republic of China 
with doubling urban development lending in 2003–2004 there. The United Kingdom’s Department for International 
Development and German Agency for Technical Cooperation routinely integrates CDS and CWS programs into 
their development operations, including Asia.  
8  The TA first appeared in ADB Business Opportunities (Internet edition) on 9 May 2005.

2   
II.  ISSUES 
4.  Two thirds of the world's poor, who live on less than a dollar a day, live in Asia. 
Increasingly, a greater proportion of the poor will live in cities. Approximately one third of the 
urban population lives in informal settlements, where access to basic services is limited and 
overcrowding is the norm. Poor living conditions and environmental degradation are prevalent 
and have threatened to erode the many social and economic gains made in cities. For example, 
the share of population with access to improved sanitation facilities was 20–50% in 20009 
throughout the region. Many Asian cities have limited management capabilities. Capability to 
manage air quality is weak, particularly in cities where air pollution levels remain high or are 
increasing. The economic impacts of urban pollution as loss of productivity and health costs 
have been estimated at 1–5% of GDP. As a result of lack of investments, most major urban 
areas have limited infrastructure, and the cost of meeting urgent needs is staggering.  
 
5.  Asia’s urban population is now estimated to be about 1.2 billion, of which about 20% is 
poor. One in three Asians lived in a city or town in 2003. By 2030, Asia’s projected urban 
population will nearly double. By that time one in two Asians will live in the cities or 2 billion 
more people will have moved to the world’s urban centers. 
 
6.  In 2004, estimates suggested that to sustain the level of growth in Asia, about $400 
billion per year would need to be invested in urban infrastructure for the next 25 years. This 
amounted to $12 trillion in mid-2004 prices over 25 years. ADB is bridging this gap in a number 
of ways—from investing in infrastructure; improving the financing of cities, including through 
currency swaps and issuance of local currency bonds; introducing national policy reforms; to 
building capacity, and so on.10  
 
7.  More recently many sociopolitical changes such as decentralization, democratization, 
globalization, and advances in technology have presented many challenges to urban areas in 
the  Asia  and  Pacific  region.  Governments  need  to  respond  not  only  to  rising  poverty, 
environmental  degradation,  and  rapid  population  growth,  but  also  to  economic  growth; 
competition of cities with other places; information technology; the need for better governance, 
planning, and urban management; and the need to improve the quality of the environment. 
 
8.  In  the  face  of  these  challenges,  cities  need  to  maximize  resources,  make  their 
development strategies coherent, improve governance, sustain a viable financial strategy, and 
scale up their efforts to make infrastructure and services work for all, particularly for the poor. All 
these will require citywide initiatives that are more effective than segmented local interventions. 
Governments need to mobilize broad-based collaborative action to meet the various challenges 
of  making  cities  more  livable,  productive,  and  competitive.  External  agencies  should  work 
together and focus more sharply on specific targets. Cities should also develop new approaches 
to  integrate  themselves  into  the wider  urban  and  regional  economies  and  to sustain  their 
development.  
 
9.  CA focuses on cities. It is a resource that ADB should be able to utilize fully. It provides a 
link  to  resources,  collective  know-how,  best  practices,  and  experience  of  partner  cities  in 
responding to the many challenges facing them. About 150 cities in 27 countries have adopted 
the CDS and CWS.  
                                                 
9  World Health Organization http://www.developmentgoals.org/Environment.htm 
10  Lohani, Bindu. 2005. Financing the City: ADB’s Perspective. Paper presented at the Asian Development Bank 
Annual Meeting, Turkey, May 2005.

3
 
10.  As a CA member, ADB together with partner cities can access grant funds for project 
preparatory activities, advocacy initiatives, and CDS- and CWS-related programs. Grant funds 
from CA are not routed through ADB. If parallel ADB activities are to be better coordinated and 
more coherent, channeling of funds needs to be improved. 
 
11.  CA has approved grants for a total of $1 million for two ADB applications: the Philippines 
Integrated  Approaches  to  Poverty  Reduction  at  the  Neighborhood  Level—a  CWS  initiative 
approved  for  $500,000  in  2004,  and  the  City  and  Regional  Development  Strategies  for 
Azerbaijan, approved for $500,000 in 2005. The Philippine project will run parallel to the $30.6 
million  Development  of  Poor  Urban  Communities  Sector  Project  loan.  Work  on  a  project 
preparatory  TA  to  support  city  and  regional  development  will  be  closely  related  to  the 
preparation of city and regional development strategies in Azerbaijan. CDS will be used to 
initiate targeted, coherent, and synergistic forward annual lending, TA, and economic and sector 
work. 
 
12.  ADB has access to CA’s body of knowledge and lessons learned and good practices on 
reducing urban poverty. ADB is represented in the CA Consultative Group, which guides CA’s 
policies and work program. 
 
13.  ADB is reviewing its urban sector strategy11 to assess its efficacy and to identify areas 
where  it  could  be  updated,  improved,  or  strengthened.  The  review  is  important  as  ADB 
improves  the  thrust  and  quality  of  its  urban  operations.  The  review  will  seek  inputs  from 
development partners and cities involved in CA activities that have vast experience in urban 
affairs and strong focus on achieving the Millennium Development Goals, specifically 9, 10, and 
11.12  
 
14.  Considering the benefits of CA membership and the potential for leveraging resources to 
support ADB’s operational program, continued membership in Cities Alliance for 3 years is 
proposed through this TA. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
15.  The TA aims to help improve the quality and developmental impact of urban investments 
in the region. The TA will provide for ADB’s continued membership in CA for 3 years and 
consolidate ADB’s participation in CA.  
 
16.   With its continued membership, ADB envisages to (i) promote CDS and CWS to reduce 
urban poverty among developing member countries (DMCs) and partner cities throughout the 
region;  and  (ii)  prepare  applications  to  CA  for  grants  to  assist  with  project  identification, 
preparation, and capacity building to support the urban sector and strengthen partnerships. 
 
                                                 
11  ADB. 1999. Urban Sector Strategy. Manila. 
12  MDG target 9 aims to halve, by 2015, the proportion of people living in extreme poverty; target 10, to halve, by 
2015, the proportion of people living without access to safe drinking water; and target 11, to significantly improve, 
by 2020, the lives of 100 million slum dwellers.

4   
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
17.  The Energy, Transport and Water Division (RSID) of the Regional and Sustainable 
Development (RSDD) will assist the regional departments and facilitate the preparations and 
applications for CA grants that support urban sector operations. Regional departments are 
expected to initiate and finance these activities from their own operational budgets. Seeking 
guidance from ADB departments concerned (Office of Cofinancing Operations, Office of the 
General Counsel, and Controller’s Department), RSID will look into developing a mechanism for 
routing CA grants for applications approved in 2005–2007 through ADB instead of through other 
agencies as is the case now.  
 
18.  Through its membership in CA, ADB will actively link partner cities with CA resources 
such as the grant fund facility; collective know-how and experience; and networks of local 
authorities, urban professionals, academics, universities, and urban policy research institutes to 
encourage cities to develop tools and practical approaches for application. ADB will continue to 
sit in the CA Consultative Group.   
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
19.  The total cost of the TA is estimated at $750,000. The Cooperation Fund for the Water 
Sector is funding $150,000 through an approved TA.13 ADB's TA funding program will finance 
$600,000. ADB will remit a total of $750,000 or $250,000 per year to CA to comprise ADB's 
membership contribution for 3 years.  
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
20.  ADB will be the Executing Agency for the TA. ADB’s contribution of core funds in the 
amount of $250,000 annually (2004/2005, 2005/2006, and 2006/2007) will be deposited in the 
CA–ADB  Trust  Fund in  accordance  with  the memorandum  of  agreement  signed  in  March 
2003.14 The TA will be implemented over 24 months, from August 2005 to July 2007. 
 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
21.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision  of  $600,000  on  a  grant  basis,  for  the  Asian  Development  Bank's  Continued 
Participation in the Cities Alliance, and hereby reports this action to the Board.
